metadata.case_name: First Income-tax Officer v. Liquidators of M/s. Short Brothers Private Ltd.

facts.text: On December 24, 1959, M/s. Short Brothers Private Ltd. sold its coffee estates and other assets.
By resolution dated February 6, 1960, it was resolved that the company be voluntarily wound up and liquidators be appointed.
Out of the proceeds realized by sale of its assets, the liquidators distributed on March 30, 1960 Rs. 8,50,000 to the shareholders.

By letter dated December 19, 1960, the Income-tax Officer, Salem, informed the liquidators that he proposed to treat that amount distributed as dividends and to call upon the liquidators to pay the tax deductible under S. 18(3D) of the Income-tax Act.

Liquidators submitted that the amount was capital appreciation from sale of agricultural lands and buildings, not liable to tax, and in any event represented current profits not dividend under S. 2(6A)(c).
Income-tax Officer by order dated October 18, 1962 called upon liquidators to pay Rs. 4,11,700 retained from distribution.
Liquidators filed Writ Petition No. 1242 of 1962 in Madras High Court for writ of prohibition restraining ITO from enforcing collection.

Madras High Court by judgment dated October 3, 1963 held demand not in conformity with law as no determination if portion represented capital gains from agricultural lands, issued writ restraining enforcement, liberty to re-examine.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether High Court could exercise jurisdiction under Art. 226 bypassing assessment machinery.
Whether profits of the current year (till resolution for winding up) are 'accumulated profits' under S. 2(6A)(c) and thus dividend on distribution.
Whether capital appreciation from sale of lands yielding agricultural income (not taxable as capital gains) forms part of accumulated profits under S. 2(6A)(c) and is dividend on distribution.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court bypassed adequate assessment and rectification machinery under Income-tax Act by entertaining writ under Art. 226.
Entire Rs. 8,50,000 distributed is liable as dividend under S. 2(6A)(c) and S. 12, whatever source.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 2(6A)(c), S. 12 Income-tax Act; Mrs. Bacha Guzdar v. CIT

petitioner_arguments.text: Current profits are included in accumulated profits immediately before liquidation.

respondent_arguments.text: Amount distributed was capital appreciation from agricultural lands and buildings, not liable to tax.
Amounts represented current profits of the year of winding up resolution, not dividend under S. 2(6A)(c).
Accumulated profits do not include capital gains per Explanation to S. 2(6A)(c).

court_reasoning.text: High Court has discretion under Art. 226 to entertain writ despite alternative remedies; no interference with discretion.
Accumulated profits under S. 2(6A)(c) include profits till immediately before liquidation, including current profits of part-year; legislative history confirms this.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No ground to read statute artificially; amendments supersede prior views like Burrell and Sheth Haridas.

court_reasoning.text: Capital appreciation from agricultural lands not capital gains under S. 12B and S. 2(4A); realization of capital rise, not profits; thus not part of accumulated profits or dividend.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accumulated profits are commercial profits plus defined capital gains; agricultural land gains excluded.

court_reasoning.text: Explanation to S. 2(6A)(c) implies accumulated profits include capital gains outside excepted periods.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Negative form does not exclude capital gains from substantive definition.

holdings.text: High Court's exercise of Art. 226 jurisdiction upheld.
Current profits till immediately before liquidation are accumulated profits and dividend under S. 2(6A)(c).
Capital appreciation from agricultural lands not capital gains, not accumulated profits, not dividend on distribution.

precedents_cited.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. George Burrell
precedents_cited.relevance: Held current profits on liquidation not taxable as income; superseded by 1939 amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sheth Haridas Achratlal v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Broken period profits not previous year; superseded by 1955/1956 amendments.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mrs. Bacha Guzdar v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Petitioner relied on it for dividend from agricultural profits taxable; court addressing.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of dividend includes distributions from accumulated profits on liquidation; excludes agricultural land capital gains; charge on other sources includes dividends.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court jurisdiction for writs including prohibition.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax (Amendment) Act, 1947
Income-tax (Amendment) Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced special definition of dividend cl.(c).

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's jurisdiction and view that ITO must determine portion attributable to accumulated profits excluding non-taxable agricultural capital appreciation, but held current profits are included in accumulated profits.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court writ upheld with clarification on current profits.

key_quotes.text: "The Explanation plainly implies that within the expression accumulated profits are included capital gains outside the excepted periods."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets scope of accumulated profits under S. 2(6A)(c).

key_quotes.text: "Accumulated profits are therefore profits which are so regarded in commercial practice, and capital gains as defined in the Income-tax Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes commercial profits from excluded agricultural gains.

key_quotes.text: "distribution which is attributable to the accumulated profits of the Company immediately before its liquidation is to be deemed dividend."
key_quotes.speaker: court
